p: The absence of antioxidant activity in the DPPH assay, for the essential oil in this study, may be explained by the fact that terpene compounds are not capable of donating a hydrogen atom [ 46]. However, in the investigations of antioxidant activity of lipophilic substances, the ABTS method has been proven to be appropriate for essential oils [ 47]. The results of this study indicate that the activity of compounds with proven in vivo antioxidant activity, such as 1,8-cineole [ 48], are being antagonized by other compounds present in the essential oil, since the EO did not present antioxidant activity in the in vitro test, which is an assay directly related to the nature of the compound (the compound must not be metabolized) [ 49] and of which the mechanism is known [ 50]. We suggest that the absence of in vitro antioxidant activity in P. carpunya essential oils mainly consisting of monoterpene and sesquiterpene, which have antioxidant activity, may be due to antagonism with other compounds.
